definition: A Teacher Performance Assessment (TPA) is an evaluation for aspiring teachers to confirm they have the knowledge and skills for effective teaching. It uses a portfolio of their clinical practice including lesson plans video recordings of teaching and student work samples.
Category of related services provided to a student with disabilities. E.g. Speech OT PT APE etc.
Functional behavior assessments aim to identify the underlying reason for the behavior
A written plan for students with disabilities that outlines special education services goals and accommodations
A plan that provides accommodations and modifications for students with disabilities under Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act
A multi-tier approach to identify and support students with learning and behavior needs
A framework for creating positive school environments and supporting student behavior
Students who are learning English as a second language
Programs and instruction designed for non-native English speakers
The right of students with disabilities to receive education at no cost that meets their individual needs
Requirement that students with disabilities be educated with non-disabled peers to the maximum extent appropriate
A plan based on FBA results that includes positive strategies to address challenging behaviors
Equipment or services used to increase maintain or improve functional capabilities of students with disabilities
Related service that helps students develop fine motor skills and daily living skills needed for school success
Related service that addresses gross motor skills mobility and physical development needs
Professional who provides speech and language therapy services
Modified physical education program designed to meet the needs of students with disabilities
Team of professionals who evaluate and plan services for students with disabilities
The school district or other local administrative unit responsible for providing educational services
Required written communication to parents explaining any proposed or refused changes to their child's identification

fullForm: Family Educational Rights and Privacy Act
definition: Federal law protecting the privacy of student education records and giving parents rights to access and control disclosure of their child's records
Civil rights law prohibiting discrimination based on disability in public accommodations employment transportation and telecommunications

fullForm: California Assessment of Student Performance & Progress
definition: California's statewide assessment system measuring student progress toward mastering state standards in English language arts and mathematics
Regional consortium of school districts that work together to provide special education services and ensure compliance with state and federal requirements
Specially designed instruction provided by qualified special education teachers to address the unique needs of students with disabilities
Alternative communication method using pictures that allows non-speaking individuals to initiate communication and make requests
Developmental disability significantly affecting verbal and nonverbal communication and social interaction generally evident before age three
Significantly below-average intellectual functioning existing concurrently with deficits in adaptive behavior manifested during the developmental period
Disorder in one or more basic psychological processes involved in understanding or using language that affects ability to listen think speak read write spell or do math calculations
Condition exhibiting one or more characteristics over a long period affecting educational performance: inability to learn build relationships inappropriate behavior/feelings or pervasive unhappiness
Communication disorder such as stuttering impaired articulation language impairment or voice impairment that adversely affects educational performance
Having limited strength vitality or alertness due to chronic or acute health problems that adversely affect educational performance
Acquired injury to the brain caused by external physical force resulting in total or partial functional disability or psychosocial impairment affecting educational performance
Impairment in vision that even with correction adversely affects educational performance including both partial sight and blindness
Hearing impairment so severe that the child is impaired in processing linguistic information through hearing with or without amplification
Methods and tools used to supplement or replace speech for individuals with communication impairments
Intermediate educational agency between the state and local school districts that provides support services and oversight
State agency that conducts impartial due process hearings for special education disputes between parents and school districts
Impartial hearing officer who conducts due process hearings and makes binding decisions on special education disputes
Standardized assessment tool used to diagnose autism spectrum disorders through structured activities and observations
A method for teaching desired behaviors skills or tasks by breaking down the skill into small discrete steps that are taught in a highly structured and hierarchical manner with systematic rewards
Diagnostic tool used to identify children with autism and distinguish them from children with other developmental delays
Profile of autism characterized by an extreme avoidance of everyday demands and expectations coupled with high levels of anxiety
Condition that affects how the nervous system receives and responds to sensory information often co-occurring with autism
Individual aide assigned to provide dedicated support to a specific student
School health professional who provides medical support and health-related services
School health professional who supervises health services and provides complex medical care coordination
Professional who teaches travel skills and spatial awareness to students with visual impairments
Private organization that provides special education services under contract with school districts
Private school that serves students with disabilities under contract with school districts
Comprehensive plan that includes positive strategies to address challenging behaviors based on functional assessment
Professional certified to provide behavior analysis services including assessment and intervention design
Paraprofessional who practices under the supervision of a BCBA to implement behavior intervention plans

fullForm: Present Levels of Academic Achievement and Functional Performance
definition: Section of the IEP that describes the student's current academic achievement and functional performance
Special education services provided beyond the normal school year to prevent significant regression of skills
Regular education classroom setting where students without disabilities typically receive instruction
Self-contained special education classroom for students who need intensive support
Special education program providing support to students with disabilities in the general education setting
Therapy based on the science of learning and behavior that applies understanding of how behavior works to increase helpful behaviors and decrease harmful behaviors or those affecting learning
Neurodevelopmental disorder affecting attention span impulse control and activity level usually first diagnosed in childhood
Developmental disability significantly affecting verbal and nonverbal communication and social interaction
Visual language using hand gestures body language and facial expressions used by the deaf and hard of hearing community
Condition characterized by patterns of disruptive or problematic behaviors that interfere with learning and social interactions
Below-average intellectual functioning that affects a student's ability to learn and process information
Condition where a child does not reach developmental milestones at the expected times in areas such as physical movement communication cognitive or social and emotional skills

fullForm: Dynamic Indicators of Basic Early Literacy Skills
definition: Standardized assessment tool used to measure early literacy skills and predict reading proficiency

fullForm: Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders
definition: Handbook used by health care professionals as the authoritative guide to the diagnosis of mental disorders
Services and supports provided to infants and toddlers with developmental delays or disabilities and their families
Having partial or complete hearing loss that adversely affects educational performance
Federal law ensuring students with disabilities are provided with Free Appropriate Public Education tailored to their individual needs
Neurological condition that affects the brain's ability to receive process store and respond to information
Pattern of angry irritable mood argumentative defiant behavior or vindictiveness toward authority figures
System of interventions designed to improve quality of life and reduce problem behaviors through teaching appropriate alternative behaviors
Group of disorders characterized by delays in the development of socialization and communication skills
Language teaching method that combines speech with physical movement where students respond to verbal commands with physical actions to reinforce learning and comprehension
Database system used to manage and track special education student data services and compliance requirements
